Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Measuring the Stability of Web Links

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
With every passing day, the Internet becomes more and more integrated in society. Our reliance on online web services in our professional and personal lives continuously increases. Recognizing this, attackers take advantage of the web's popularity to mount a wide range of web application attacks, compromising systems, and stealing private and financial information. Although many classes of these attacks are seemingly unrelated, in reality, many of them stem from the stateless nature of the web, where no safeguards exist to ensure that a resource that was linked to yesterday is the same resource being accessed today. As a result, enforcing link integrity holds the promise of mitigating a multitude of security attacks.

However, the dynamicity of the web poses challenges to link integrity schemes, which must cope with constant benign changes while flagging the malicious ones. Pursuing this line of research requires a fundamental understanding of the security aspects of the web?s dynamic nature. This nature cannot be assessed today with the available tools, because existing web crawlers are limited to retrieving content, and generally do not gather the metadata critical to the development of link integrity schemes. This project aims to quantify the stability of web links by developing a custom web crawler infrastructure and tools that will collect security-related metadata about remote resources. The gathering and subsequent assessing of this metadata is a critical first step to demonstrate the feasibility of developing robust link integrity schemes that can be used to detect abnormal content and infrastructure changes (indicative of an ongoing attack) while keeping false positives to a minimum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we aimed to quantify the stability of linked resources in the world wide web.  Our goal was to assess whether it is possible to depend on the integrity of remote content to provide security on the modern web. If the properties of web content are sufficiently stable, web page links can be augmented with information that allows a web browser to verify the integrity of the remote content at the target of the link.  These integrity-based mechanisms can defend against a wide range of web security issues, including malicious advertising, domain name hijacking, and attacks against search engines. Specifically, we investigated the attacks that are possible when these integrity schemes are absent and developed tools and techniques that collect website data that allow us to reason about the dynamicity of the modern web.

 

We developed custom web crawlers, DNS taps, and tools for gathering network data.  We used these tools to confirm that the web is indeed dynamic, but that the dynamicity is constrained to specific sets of IP addresses, content distribution networks, and autonomous systems. Our results therefore indicate that, as hypothesized, there is sufficient stability in the world wide web to make integrity-based security viable, which can pave the way for the design, implementation, and evaluation of integrity-based schemes. In fact, our findings suggest that integrity-based schemes can significantly harden the security of the web.

 

Additionally, through our experiments, we observed that the lack of integrity of remote content does not only affect the web, but also the technologies on which the web relies. Namely, we showed that attackers can hijack thousands of domain names by abusing expired records that previously belonged to reputable owners. Similarly, we investigated a new type of domain squatting (called combosquatting) where attackers register domains that include trademarks of popular companies. Some of the maliciously-registered domains used to belong to legitimate companies prior their expiration. We found that combosquatting is more popular than other types of domain squatting and showed that attackers utilize these domains to conduct a wide range of attacks including phishing, malware delivery, trademark abuse, and affiliate-program abuse.

 

Beyond the aforementioned research, this project allowed graduate students (at PhD and MS levels) to develop expertise in crawler construction, network protocols, and big-data analytics in addition to experimenting with virtualization on public cloud providers. All of these skills are valuable for their future careers, for the advancement of national prosperity, and for securing the national defense.
